content:
Diagnosis:
Locally advanced p16 positive oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, cT2N1M0 (Stage II)

Previous treatment:
Completed radical chemoradiotherapy March 2024 (70Gy in 35 fractions with concurrent weekly cisplatin)

Current medications:
Ondansetron 8mg bd
Dexamethasone 4mg bd
Co-codamol 30/500mg qds
Artificial saliva spray prn

Current situation:
Seen today for week 6 review during radiotherapy

I reviewed [redacted name] today who is experiencing significant treatment-related toxicity. He has developed grade 3 mucositis requiring increased analgesia and affecting his oral intake. His weight has dropped by 4kg over the past 2 weeks despite dietary supplementation. He is managing only liquid nutrition and requires regular breakthrough morphine. He has also developed grade 2 radiation dermatitis affecting his neck. His performance status has deteriorated to ECOG 2.

On examination today, there is severe mucositis affecting the oropharynx with confluent ulceration. The skin reaction is confluent erythema without breakdown. His blood results show stable renal function but his magnesium has dropped to 0.62.

Given the severity of his symptoms and impact on quality of life, we have made the decision to pause his radiotherapy after today's fraction (fraction 30/35). He will be reviewed again on Monday with blood tests, and if there is improvement in his mucositis we will consider completing the final 5 fractions. I have also held his cisplatin for this week.

He has been given subcutaneous fluids and magnesium replacement today. The speech and language team have reviewed him and provided additional support for safe swallowing. I have arranged daily reviews by our specialist nurses and provided emergency contact details.

The plan is to review on Monday with blood tests including magnesium level. If oral intake has not improved by then, we will arrange hospital admission for supportive care.
